newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: WTO sets panel in "Kodak-Fuji" film dispute.
newsitem.headline: WTO sets panel in "Kodak-Fuji" film dispute.

text.p: The World Trade Organisation on Wednesday agreed to set up a panel to look into a U.S. complaint that Japan rigs its photofilm market to keep out foreign products, officials said.

The European Union asked to join the dispute as a third party at the WTO's Dispute Settlement Body (DSB), whose decision was automatic as it was the second U.S. request for a panel in what is known as the "Kodak-Fuji" dispute.

Eastman Kodak asked Washington to take up the case, saying Japanese laws had prevented it challenging the dominance of Fuji in its home market, causing it to lose business worth $5.6 billion over the last decade.
But U.S. officials say the problem reflects a range of regulations and laws used by Japan to counteract its obligations to ensure free trade under WTO accords.
Japan denies the allegations and counters that Kodak has a control of the U.S. domestic photofilm market very similar to Fuji's own 70 per cent at home.

According to trade sources, Afga Gevaert, the photographic film and product unit of German chemical giant Bayer AG, approached the European Commission over the issue, saying it, like Kodak, had serious problems in penetrating the lucrative Japanese domestic market.
